quote: Keep back.
Both of you put your weapons down.
I can't do that, Captain.
You heard him...
What happened?
How long have you two been apart?
At least a minute.
Then we've got a problem. Any of us could be the changeling. You, Kira, Eddington... even me.
Not you.
What do you mean?
You're bleeding.
I cut my hand when the Changeling attacked me.
What are you getting at?
When blood leaves a humanoid body... it's still blood. But when any part of me separates from my body...
It reverts back to a gelatinous state.
Sisko to Bashir.
This is Bashir.
Doctor, meet us in the Mess Hall immediately.
This should only take a second.
Satisfied?
So far.
Who's next?
I'll go.
I'd say the major is exactly who she appears to be.
Try not to look so surprised.
(to Eddington and Sisko) There doesn't seem to be much of a point in obtaining a sample from the Constable, so I guess that leaves the three of us.
Let's get this over with.
I think you'd better come with me.
Look, this is ridiculous. I'm not the changeling. If I were, don't you think I'd put up a little more of a fight?
Inside.
You're making a mistake.
Do as he says.
Would someone please get me out of here?
Bridge to Captain Sisko.
Sisko here.
Captain... we're entering Tzenkethi space.
Any sign of Tzenkethi ships?
Sensors aren't picking up any warp signatures.
We've altered course. Our new heading is zero-one-five mark four-seven. We're headed directly for the Tzenkethi settlement on M'kemas Three.
How long before we're in weapons range of the settlement?
Twelve minutes.
Computer, this is Captain Benjamin Sisko. Initiate auto-destruct sequence. Authorization Sisko Alpha One Alpha.
Identity confirmed. Additional authorization required.
This is First Officer Kira Nerys. Auto-destruct authorization Kira Beta Two Beta.
Identity confirmed. Auto-destruct sequence armed.
Set the countdown for ten minutes from my mark. Authorization Sisko One-Five Destruct. Mark.
Sequence initiated. Auto-destruct in nine minutes, fifty seconds.
Sisko to O'Brien.
O'Brien here.
I could use some good news right now, Chief.
How about this... I think I may be able to shut down the changeling's forcefields and gain access to the sabotaged systems. The only problem is, there's a chance we'll lose our own forcefields, too.
Auto-destruct in seven minutes.
Just tell me how long it will take.
I guess it'll have to be less than seven minutes.
That'd be my suggestion. Sisko out.
Doctor... how's Lieutenant Dax?

Still unconscious. The changeling gave her enough sedatives to keep her under for days. I've filtered most of them out of her system, but she'll be out for at least another few hours. I wish I could do more.
You've done all you can, Doctor. Now it's up to Chief O'Brien.
Auto-destruct in six minutes.

All right, we're almost there. Look, when we set off this device there's a possibility we'll lose the protective field around the warp core. If that happens, this room's going to heat up real fast. So give the warp core a wide berth or you'll get a dose of radiation poisoning that even Bashir can't cure.
Where's the changeling? I lost him in the conduits.
We haven't seen him.
Wait... it's me. Odo.
You don't say.
Chief, remember the last time we went kayaking in the holosuites... You had lamb stew for lunch.
That's right...
But you forgot to bring a fork. Anyone could've gotten that information.
Auto-destruct in five minutes.
You'd better make a decision. We're running out of time.
I've got more important things to do than play choose the changeling. Keep a phaser on both of them.
The shuttlebay doors are sealed and the evacuation pods are locked down. We have no way out.
Weapons are fully charged and ready to fire. Tactical systems are programming an attack run on the Tzenkethi settlement.
Chief, what are you doing?
Auto-destruct in four minutes.
You'll see.
(to the Engineer, urgent) Now.
Warning. The protective field around the warp core has been breached. The engine room will be sealed in ten seconds. Evacuate immediately.
(to the Engineer, an order) Shut down the main power grid.
Engine Room sealed.
No.
Why are you protecting these solids?
You don't belong with them.
You belong with us.
Auto-destruct in three minutes.
Let go. Don't you see? You've lost. It's too late for you to help them... but it's not too late to help yourself.
Link with me, Odo. We can escape together.
I don't think so.
Auto-destruct in two minutes.
You have to regain control of the ship.
Right.
Odo...
I never wanted to harm you.
O'Brien to Bridge.
Go ahead, Chief.
I've restored control to the helm. She's all yours, Captain.
Major, hard aport. Get us away from that settlement.
Computer, end the auto-destruct sequence. Authorization Sisko Omega One Seven Abort.
This is Kira Nerys, First Officer, I concur.
Auto-destruct sequence aborted.
The phaser banks are powering down.
Take us home, major.
Captain's log, supplemental. We've returned to the station without further incident. However, I'm concerned for my chief of security, who hasn't said a word since we left Tzenkethi space.
scene: 122  EXT. SPACE - DEEP SPACE NINE - STOCK (OPTICAL)

quote: The real Ambassador Krajensky was supposed to be on his way to Risa for an extended vacation. He never arrived.
Starfleet Security believes he's been kidnapped... or possibly killed.
And the coup on the Tzenkethi homeworld?
Never happened. Starfleet Command wants detailed reports from each of us...
Odo, are you all right?
I'm... fine. I hope I'm not interrupting.
Not at all.
Have a seat.
Captain, there's something you need to know. The changeling, before he... died, he whispered something to me.
Go on.
He said, "You're too late. We're everywhere."
I found twenty-seven voles in his storeroom.
Vole infestations are not uncommon on this station. If you don't believe me, ask Chief O'Brien.
When I came in, he and Morn were painting numbers on the voles' backs.
We were just... counting them to see how many we'd caught.
You were getting ready to stage a vole fight.
A vole fight? I'm appalled. Do you really think that was what Morn was up to?
I want the voles confiscated and removed from the station.
But you can't confiscate Morn's voles. They're like... his pets.
I'll see if I can get him some goldfish. And now, if you gentlemen will excuse me, it's late.
Poor Morn. This is going to break his hearts.
Ops is yours, Lieutenant.
Going somewhere, Chief?
Sir, I need to talk to you. It's kind of private.
We were just leaving. Come on, let's go break the news to Morn.
Do you want to talk in my office?
Actually, I thought we'd go to my place.
Get onto the transporter pad... Now.
What do you think you're doing?
Just get on the pad.
Computer, energize on my command.
Energize.
Where are we?
I guess you might say we just stepped through the looking glass.
Why don't you sit down... make yourself comfortable?
Maybe I'm not feeling too comfortable right now.
There, that's better.
That was a pretty good move.
I'm glad you liked it.
But it still doesn't change anything. You can't go home unless I reconfigure the transporter, and I'm not about to do that. I guess you've got a lot of questions.
Not as many as you think.
You know where we are?
If I had to guess, I'd say this is the same parallel universe that two of my crewmembers visited a year ago.
You're quick. Just like our Sisko.

That saves me having to give you a history lesson. But I'd better update you on current events. Since your officers left, we've started a rebellion against the Klingon/Cardassian Alliance. We're fighting for our lives.
I wish you luck, but I don't see what that has to do with me.
It has everything to do with you. You were the leader of the Terran Rebellion. At least, our Benjamin Sisko was.
Was?
Captain Sisko's dead. The Cardassians blew up his ship.
And you want me to take his place.
Like I said, you're quick.
Well I've got a better idea. We're going to walk back to the transporter pad and you're going to send me home.
Wait. Hear me out. I'm not asking for a lifetime commitment. I just need you to finish the mission Sisko was on when he was killed.
I'm sorry, but you're going to have to find someone else. I don't belong here and I'm not about to interfere with events in this universe.
At least let me tell you about the mission. And then if you decide you don't want to help, I'll send you home.

There's a Terran scientist working for the Alliance. According to our sources, she's close to completing a new transpectral sensor array that will allow the Alliance to locate our bases in the Badlands. Without a safe place to hide, the Alliance will be able to track us down and kill us all.
So you want me to make sure this scientist never finishes her project.
Captain Sisko was convinced he could change her mind, get her to work for us instead.
How did he plan to do that?
She was his wife.
Jennifer.
You know her?
She was my wife, too. But in my universe, she's dead.
Not here she isn't. Not yet, anyway.
What do you mean "not yet?"
If you don't convince Professor Sisko to join our cause, we'll have no choice but to kill her.
Kill her?
We can't allow her to finish the sensor array. It'd mean the end of the rebellion.
I can't let her die. Not again.
You're the only one who can save her.
Delectable.
And so are you.
Enter.
Mister Garak said you wanted to see me?
That's right... Come... join us.
If you're wondering when the new sensor array will be finished, the answer is--
As soon as possible. I know.
Will that be all? I have to get back to work.
I have news about your husband.
Nothing you could tell me about Ben would interest me. I haven't even seen him in five years.
I know that. And I hope that will make this easier for you. You see... Benjamin is dead.
Can I go now?
You must've loved him very much to be so angry with him. To have become... so cold.
Were other Terrans killed with him?
A whole ship full.
All this killing. It has to stop.

And it will. As soon as you complete your transpectral sensors. Once we locate the rebel bases, we can disarm them and put an end to all this bloodshed. And I can resume pressing the Alliance to be more reasonable to its Terran population.
You do believe me, don't you?
So it's agreed. I help you get Jennifer away from the Alliance,
You get us Jennifer and we'll do anything you want. I just hope you can convince her to leave Terok Nor.
I don't understand what she's doing helping the Alliance in the first place. I mean, didn't she know Sisko was leading the Rebellion?
Oh, she knew. The truth is... She and Captain Sisko didn't get along too well. But then again, the captain didn't really get along with anyone.
In some ways I think the rebellion's better off without him. Don't get me wrong, the captain knew how to fight... but that's about all he knew.
Ready?
You don't look very confident, Chief...
You better start calling me Smiley. That's what the Captain called me.
All right... "Smiley."
I just wish we had more time to get you ready. I probably haven't told you half of what you need to know. I hope you don't run up against too many surprises.
If I do, I guess I'll just have to... improvise.
I told Sisko he'd never get close to Terok Nor, and I was right.
I say we teach the Alliance a lesson. Throw everything we've got at Terok Nor and rip it to pieces.
I disagree. Following your suggestion would do nothing to enhance our goals and would result in a significant loss of life.
That's easy for you to say. Those Cardassian pigs didn't kill your brother.
We have all suffered losses at the hands of the Alliance. Nonetheless, logic dictates caution in the face of a superior enemy.
Logic isn't going to win us our freedom. We have to take action.
And we will. But this time we do it my way.
And what do you propose we do?
We smuggle explosives on board the station, plant them in her quarters, and detonate them.
You realize it's highly unlikely that anyone assigned to such a mission would survive.
I say it's worth the risk.
Does that mean you're volunteering for the job?
Captain... You're back... Where have you been... Captain Sisko...
Captain, you're alive.
Of course he's alive. You can't kill the Captain. He's too ornery to die.
I hope I haven't disappointed anyone.
We're glad you're all right.
I'm sure you are.
We heard your fighter had been destroyed. The Alliance said you were dead.
Just their propaganda machine, working overtime. But you know what that tells me? They're scared.
And we're going to give them plenty of reasons to stay scared.
It's about time you came back.
Jadzia.
That's to let you know I missed you.
And that's for letting me think you were dead.
Glad to see you still care.
You coming or not?
I thought you said I was married.
You are... technically. She's your mistress.
I see what you meant by surprises.
I really am glad you're alive.
And I'm going to make you glad you're alive, too.
We have a lot of planning to do.
It can wait.
I suppose it can at that.
These progress reports are unacceptable. Productivity in the Ore Processing Center is down fifteen percent. We've got to do better. Or are you purposely trying to make me look bad to Sector Command?
Not at all. I've done everything I can think of to motivate the workers.
Such as?
Bribes... torture... I've even given the overseers permission to execute any worker who's not meeting the quota.
I'm sure that pleases the overseers, but it's not getting the job done. Come with me.
Lets start with... Him, him, and her.
And do what?
Execute them. I think you'll find that random and unprovoked executions will keep your entire workforce alert and motivated.
I bow to your brilliance.
Though I hope your mood improves before we run out of workers.
What does my mood have to do with anything?
If you don't mind my saying so, I have noticed a certain amount of ill- humor on your part lately.
I don't know what you're talking about.
As I recall, it began about the time you learned of Captain Sisko's death.
Why would I be upset by such delightful news?
I was always under the impression that you were rather fond of him.
Then you were mistaken.
I will say one thing for him. He had spirit.
Too much spirit can be a dangerous thing. It tends to infect others.
At least that's something we won't have to worry about anymore. With Sisko's death, and the imminent completion of the transpectral sensor array, the Rebellion is certain to collapse.
You sound very sure of yourself.
I am.
I'll remember that. That way if the Rebellion continues, I'll know who to blame.
Are you sure these Alliance patrol patterns are accurate?
You tell me. You're the one who gathered the information.
Oh, that's right.
Are you okay? You seem distracted.
Just thinking.
I've been thinking, too. You know, we've been fighting against the Alliance for almost a year now. And what has it gotten us? Nothing.
Sometimes I feel we were better off when we were collecting tribute for the Intendant.
Those days are gone.
Maybe... but I'm tired of living like this. The rebellion's a lost cause and we both know it.
Don't you want to see the Terrans gain their freedom?

Have you taken a good look at your troops lately? They're nothing but ex-slaves with delusions of grandeur. They'll never overthrow the Alliance. Let's just take a ship and go... Forget all about the rebellion.
I'm not ready to give up just yet.
It's not like you're going to have much of a choice... once that witch you married finishes her new sensor array, Alliance ships are going to be all over these Badlands. We'll have no place to hide.
Then I suppose we'd better make sure she doesn't finish.
Trying to reach Terok Nor using small fighters didn't work. But we need to get Jennifer off that station, and we need to do it soon.
We've been meaning to talk to you about that.
Mister Bashir is not convinced that you can persuade your former mate to join our cause.
I can be very persuasive.
Look, I don't even know why we're bothering to discuss this. The Cardassians destroyed your ship before you even got close to Terok Nor.

(overlapping (overlapping, with O'Brien) aside to Sisko) And even if you had made Hit him. it there, there was no guarantee you could've That's what the Captain convinced your wife of would do. anything. Go on, hit him. Let's face it, Captain, the woman hates you.
Go on, hit him. Let's face it, Captain, the woman hates you.
What my wife thinks of me is no concern of yours.
Anyone else want to disagree with the captain?
Put it away, Dax. (off her surprised look) Go on, put it away.
No one's questioning your authority, Captain. But we've got to stop your wife before she finishes that sensor array.
And there's only one sure way to do that.
We have to kill her.
You've been saying that all along.
And maybe it's time he listened.
Killing her would be a lot easier than trying to get her away from the Alliance.
Easier... but not smarter. If she's so important to the Alliance, think how important she'd be to us. I mean, we could use a scientist on our side.
You tell them, Smiley. At least someone here is using their brain.
Think about it. Who knows what other weapons the Alliance is developing. Someone like Professor Sisko could counteract anything they come up with.
She's valuable to us. We need her. Now, does anyone disagree?
Good, then let's get to work.
Tell the Intendant what you told me.
It's about Captain Sisko.
Sisko?
He's alive. He was able to get off his ship before it exploded.
I suppose it's possible.
It's more than possible. It's true. But I can tell you how to get your hands on him. If you're interested.
Don't do that.
I can't help it. It itches. I hope this works.
It'll work. Just stop scratching.
You know, you did pretty good back there. I don't think anyone suspected you weren't Captain Sisko. At least not once you hit Bashir.
But you and I both know that was just a warm up. Jennifer's the one I really have to convince.
I guess seeing her isn't going to be easy for you. How long's it been since your wife died?
Five years.
Well just remember... Jennifer may look like your wife, but she's not. She's a different person.
I'll try to remember that. Do you have any idea what went wrong between her and Captain Sisko?

From what I heard, they never should've been together in the first place. I mean she came from one of the few privileged Terran families, people who "cooperated" with the Alliance, and the captain... he fought his way up from the mines.
So what's she like, this Jennifer?
I wouldn't know. They separated before I met the captain. What was your Jennifer like?
She was the kindest, most caring person I ever knew.
I wouldn't get my hopes up.
(continuing, off console) Hold on. I'm reading a slight energy distortion in subspace.
What are the coordinates?
It's coming from all around us.
You know, Captain Sisko would've tried to fight his way out of this.
Be glad I'm not him.
Well, if it isn't the notorious "Captain" Sisko and his friend the Tinkerer.
It's good to see you, too, Intendant.
Still the same old Benjamin.
You wouldn't have me any other way.
Perhaps not. But I'm still going to kill you.
Maybe. But not right away.
You flatter yourself.
Not unjustly, I hope.
Intendant, let me teach him some manners.
All in good time. But first, whatever shall we do about O'Brien? I remember when I first saw you, Tinkerer. You were fixing something.

You were always fixing things... making things better. And everyone loved you for it. Even me. But that wasn't enough for you, was it? You couldn't be happy, staying here, being loved. You had to lash out, to betray everyone who was ever good to you. Why?
I wanted to be free.
Free? You're a Terran. You were born a slave. And you'll die a slave. Take him to ore processing. Remind him where he belongs.
What about Sisko?
Bring me to the Intendant's quarters. She'll decide what to do with me.
Of all the impudent...
Do as he says.
Intendant. I demand you...
You... "demand?"
But you promised me he'd die.
And he will... When I say so, and not a moment sooner.
Shall we?
After you.
I really don't know what to do with you.
I sympathize. It's a difficult decision. But you'll come up with something.
The only reason I can think of to keep you alive is to infuriate Garak.
What better reason do you need?
Suppose I let you live... What would I get from you in return?
What do you want?

Your loyalty. That's all I've ever wanted. For you to be at my side... to be my strong right hand. But I'm afraid I'll never be able to trust you again. Which means I'll have to dispose of you eventually. The only question is, should it be sooner, or later.
Do I get a vote?
Of course you do. It just doesn't count.
I'd better think this over.
You will let me know what you decide?
I wouldn't dream of keeping it a secret.
Jennifer.
Hello, Ben. Please leave us.
And miss this happy reunion?
You heard her.
If you need someone to beat him into submission for you, don't hesitate to call me.
All right, I'm here. What did you want to see me about?
I was hoping we could talk.
Really? You never seemed interested in talking to me when we were married.
I made a lot of mistakes back then.
Save the apologies Ben. They're not going to work. You are without a doubt, the most insensitive, self- absorbed, egotistical...
You've made your point.
I doubt it. You never listened to me before. You were too busy trying to impress every woman who crossed your path.
Where there really that many?
There were enough. And if it wasn't women, it was that ship of yours. Sometimes I think it was the only thing you ever loved.
Maybe I loved you both.
Then why did you leave me to run off and play pirate for the Intendant?
That's a good question.
And now this Rebellion of yours. Do you know how many deaths you've caused? How much destruction?
I'm fighting to help free our people.
You're fighting because you like to fight, Benjamin.
All you've accomplished is to give the Alliance an excuse to treat the Terrans even worse than before. I only hope that with your capture, the Rebellion can be ended peacefully.
Who said I'd been captured?
Oh, I suppose you came here just to see me?
Actually, I came here to rescue you.
Rescue me?
That's what I said.
I'm not going anywhere with you.
You can't stay here.
I have a job to finish.
You mean the sensor array?
That's right.
Jennifer, if you finish that array you'll destroy any hope our people have for a better future. I don't think you want that.
All I want is to put an end to all this fighting. To force the rebels to seek a peaceful settlement with the Alliance.
It's not that simple. The Alliance isn't interested in a peaceful settlement. If we lay down our arms, we'll be killed.
The Rebellion is killing people every day. It has to stop.
Not this way. Not with the Terrans still at the mercy of the Alliance.
They're your own people, Jennifer.
You've got no right to talk to me like that. Since when do you care about what happens to "our people?" You've never cared about anyone but yourself.
Maybe I've changed in the past few years.
How many times have I heard you say that?
I guess I was a pretty lousy husband.
You guess?
Look, I know it's too late for an apology...
You're right about that.
But for what it's worth, I'm sorry.
What is it?
For a second, I almost believed you.
You know what I wish? I wish I'd never met you.
And I wish things could've been better between us. But this isn't about us.
Or is it? Why are you working for the Alliance? Is it because you believe in what they're doing or is it something else?
I don't know what you're talking about.
I think you and I have been fighting each other for so long that you've gotten used to us being on opposite sides. But I'm not the enemy this time, Jennifer. The Alliance is.
The Alliance is your enemy. Not mine.
That's where you're wrong. Don't you see, you're no different than the slaves working in the Ore Processing Center. In fact, you might be even worse off. At least they know they're prisoners.
And what if I am a prisoner?
You don't have to be. You can fight back. Come with me, Jennifer.
You want me to join the Rebellion.
The way I see it... Freedom is a lot better than slavery.
Think about it.
What are you doing?
Sending a message.
You've got a subdermal communicator?
Courtesy of the Ferengi. I hope it works.
Took him long enough.
Terran, what are you doing down there?
Re-routing the central ODN processor. Intendant's orders.
I don't recall receiving clearance for any repairs.
You don't say?
All right, anyone who wants to get out of here, follow me.
I need an answer, Jennifer. Are you coming with me or not?
Do I have a choice?
Of course you do. If you want, you can go back to your quarters and forget we ever spoke.
It's up to you.
All right, but lets get one thing clear.
What's that?
I still hate you.
I know.
You still haven't told me where we're going.
Airlock Seven. There should be a ship waiting for us. Providing we can get there before the security systems reactivate.
Now what?
I'll think of something.
You see. I told you I'd think of something. Good work, Smiley.
Yeah, but the problem is there's thirty more of them behind us.
Then we'd better get to the airlock.
Something tells me that's not part of your plan.
We better find another way out of here.
Got any suggestions?
Fall back.
That was very clever, Benjamin, having one of your own men betray you so you could get aboard the station. You had me totally fooled. Luckily Mister Garak is somewhat more cynical than I.
Your Ferengi friend told us your entire plan... with a little persuasion.
I'm afraid there's no escape. Your ship's locked down, your pilot's dead. There's no way out. You might as well surrender.
If we surrender, she'll kill us.
Us, maybe, but not Jennifer.
What if we offer a trade? I stay here and she lets you live.
Benjamin, you know how I hate to be kept waiting.
I came a long way to get you out of here, and I'm not leaving without you.
What is it?
Nothing.
Smiley, how far is the Ore Processing Center?
Only a couple of levels away.
Take us there.
What for?
I'll show you when we get there.
Time's up, Benjamin... Benjamin?
He always has to make things difficult.
It's one of his least endearing qualities.
Hurry. They're right behind us.
Smiley, seal the doors.
Easy for you to say.
I'll get you out of this, I promise.
I believe you.
Captain, I don't know what you're up to, but there's no way out of this place except through that door.
Don't worry. I know what I'm doing. I just hope your Terok Nor was designed by the same Cardassian who built my Terok Nor.
You're sure they're all in there?
Good. Then we've got them. Use the manual override to open the doors.
Intendant, I trust this time you won't be so lenient with our dear Mister Sisko.
Don't worry. He's disappointed me for the last time.
Jennifer. I was so worried about you. But you're safe now. In fact, I can assure you your husband will never annoy you again.
Actually, for the first time since I met him, he's not annoying me. In fact, he's been making a lot of sense.
He can be persuasive when he wants to be. I suppose that means you won't be finishing the sensor array.
I'm a Terran.
Keep her alive. Kill the others.
I wouldn't. You'd be making a mistake.
My only mistake was not executing you in the first place.
You don't know how right you are. I've activated the station's self- destruct sequence. Unless I disarm it, this whole place will blow up in...
Nine minutes.
That's impossible. There's no way you could know the station's command access code.
Alpha Nine One Seven Five Blue.
Computer, disengage self-destruct sequence. Authorization Kira Alpha Nine One Seven Five Blue.
Authorization denied.
I changed it. You've got eight minutes and thirty seconds to let us go. Otherwise we all die.
Don't listen to him. He's bluffing.
He's not bluffing.
How do you know?
I know. Give me the new access code and I'll let you go.
You'll get the access code once my friends and I are safely away from the station. Do we have a deal?
This isn't over Benjamin. I'll hunt you down. I swear it.
You're welcome to try.
I still don't understand why you gave them the access code. You could've gotten away and still destroyed the station.
But we gave our word.
Our word. Who gives a damn whether we keep our word?
I do.
I'm glad to see the two of you are getting along.
We have a lot in common.
He's all yours.
Dax tells me you're leaving.
I'm going to pay a call on the Romulans. See if I can convince them to help us.
Then I guess this is good-bye.
Again. Jennifer, there's so much I want to say to you, but I don't know where to start...
You can start by telling me what happened to my husband.
Don't bother. I don't know who you are, but you're not Ben Sisko.
When did you figure it out?
I think I suspected from the beginning. It was your eyes.
What about them?
They're too kind. There was nothing kind about Ben. He's dead, isn't he?
I'm sorry.
Don't be. So, who are you, really?
It's a long story. Talk to Smiley. He can fill you in on the details.
He seems like a good man.
He does at that. So what are you going to do now?
Oh, I'm sure Smiley will find something to keep me busy. You're not really going to visit the Romulans, are you?
The deal was I get you off the station, and then I go home.
Will I see you again?
I don't know.
Thank you for... rescuing me.
It was... my pleasure.
Ready, Captain?
You'd better go.
Take me home, Smiley.
Where are they? They should've been back hours ago.
Maybe the meeting with Starfleet Command took longer than they thought it would.
Then why haven't Sisko or Dax contacted us?
The whole area they're traveling through is crawling with Klingon ships. The second they used their subspace transmitters, they'd become a target.
I never should've let them leave in a runabout. I should've insisted they take the Defiant.
You did. But the captain's orders were clear.
As long as we're at war with the Klingons, we need the Defiant to help protect the station.
All I know is that I'd hate to be dodging Klingon raiding parties in nothing but a runabout.
It would take a fleet of Klingon ships to breach the station's defenses. I say we take the Defiant and go looking for the captain.
I'm with Worf.
I'm glad the two of you are in agreement. But with the captain gone, I'm in charge of the station, and I say we stay.
You may be in charge of the station, major, but I command the Defiant.
Mister Worf, the captain has given us our orders and I intend for us to follow them until he issues new ones.
Hold on a minute. I'm reading a warp signature approaching the station.
It's the Rio Grande.
On screen.
Looks like they had a run in with the Klingons. Weapons systems, shields and com system are all pretty shot up.
Lifesigns?
Permission to welcome the captain back on board.
Permission granted.
Glad you made it back in one piece.
So are we.
How was your meeting with Starfleet Command?
I'm afraid the war's not going well. The Klingons are throwing everything they have at us. Starfleet's been able to slow them down, but that's about all.
It's hard to believe one changeling could cause so much chaos.
He can if he's impersonating the leader of the Klingon Empire.
So is Starfleet going to do something about "Chancellor Gowron" or not?
Oh... they're going to do something.
Starfleet's sending an infiltration team into Klingon territory. Their orders are to do whatever it takes to prove Gowron's a Shape-shifter.
Tough assignment. Who are they sending?
Me.
Captain, you're just in time for Happy Hour.
Do I look happy, Quark?

Do you think any of these people looked happy when they walked in here? How could they? There's a war going on. But they come because they know I'll do everything in my power to help them forget their troubles. For a reasonable fee, of course. Now what can I do for you?
I'm looking for Odo.
We all have our failures, Captain. And he's mine. Every since he lost his shape-shifting abilities, I haven't been able to get a smile out of him.
Where is he?
I'm telling you, Captain, that's one depressed ex-changeling. (gestures toward the stairway) He's upstairs at his usual table. Just follow the black cloud.
Constable.
Listen, Captain. Do you hear it?
You mean the bubbles?
Soothing, isn't it? You know, before I became a Solid, I never heard that. I didn't have a sense of taste so I never paid much attention to food, or drink. I had no idea how seductive they could be.
Would you like me to get you a glass?
I'm not.
I thought you were always on duty.

You know, at first, I found the whole process of ingestion... disgusting. But now that I've gotten used to it, I find eating and drinking to be quite comforting. It's one of the few things you... ... we humanoids have control over.
Not necessarily. There's always the temptation to eat too much... to drink too much...
One has to find something to do with one's time. And for some reason, my work isn't as fulfilling as it used to be.
I might be able to do something about that. Starfleet has ordered us to try to expose the Gowron changeling. I want you to come with us.
Maybe it would be better for you to take Deputy Yndar. There's nothing I can do that he can't.
I don't need Yndar. I need you. ODO What you need is someone who can turn into Gowron's pet targ. And I can't do that anymore.

character: I don't need Yndar. I need you.ODO
quote: What you need is someone who can turn into Gowron's pet targ. And I can't do that anymore.
What I need is my chief of security. There's a staff meeting at sixteen hundred hours. I expect you to be there.
According to Starfleet intelligence, Chancellor Gowron has relocated Klingon military headquarters to Ty'Gokor.
That will make our job more difficult. Ty'Gokor is located in an asteroid field deep in Klingon Space. It is probably the most heavily fortified installation in the Empire.
There're at least thirty warships stationed there at any given time and the entire asteroid field is protected by a tachyon detection grid.
Which means there's no way to get a cloaked ship within transporter range.
Even if we do find a way inside, getting close to Gowron will not be easy. He is guarded around the clock by his personal security force, the Yan-Isleth.
The Brotherhood of the Sword.
Look, I don't want to sound negative, but even if you get to Gowron, how can you prove to the Klingons he's a changeling?
I doubt he'll stand still and let us take a blood sample.
The Klingons are obsessive about blood screenings. If he's lasted this long, the changeling impersonating Gowron must've already found a way around them.
There is one solution. We could kill him.
Dead changelings do revert back to their gelatinous state.
Our orders are to expose Gowron, not assassinate him. Which is why Starfleet has given us these.
Very impressive. What are they?
They're modified polaron emitters.
Starfleet Science thinks that exposure to polaron radiation will have a destabilizing effect on changeling physiology.
In other words, if you use these on Gowron, and he is one of my people, he won't be able to retain his humanoid shape.
That's the theory.
The problem is, for it to work properly, you have to activate all four emitters at once.
I hate prototypes.
Plus, too much polaron radiaton can be fatal. Which means we can only expose a person once. Any more than that and, changeling or not, they'll die of radiation poisoning.
The plan is to smuggle these into Ty'Gokor. Once they're set up, they can cover about twelve thousand cubic meters.

So let me get this straight. All we have to do is get past an enemy fleet, avoid a tachyon detection grid, beam into the middle of Klingon headquarters and avoid the Brotherhood of the Sword long enough to set these things up and activate them in front of Gowron.
If we succeed, there will be many songs sung in our honor.
I just hope we're around to hear them.
The first problem is how to get you safely to Ty'Gokor.
That's one I think I can solve.
Ziyal.
It's so good to see you, Father.
Your message said that it was urgent I come to the station. What's wrong?
I can answer that.

Major, I must say, I'm shocked. You used my daughter to lure me here. You're asking me to risk my ship on some fool's errand into the Klingon Empire. And you're pregnant. I hope First Minister Shakaar appreciates what a lucky man he is.
Shakaar's not the father.
Then who is?
Chief O'Brien.
Well, at least there's one good thing about your condition. You won't be going on this suicidal mission.
It might not be as hopeless as you think.
How can Sisko be so deluded to think he and four of his crewmen can infiltrate Klingon military headquarters? They'll be caught in a heartbeat.
Maybe...
Maybe not.
What's wrong, Dukat? Haven't you ever seen a Klingon before?
I see we're all here.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: The ship is ready for departure.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: At your convenience, Gul Dukat.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Captain, I insist that we make a holographic record of the four of you. Consider it payment in full for the use of my vessel.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Maybe after the mission.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: After the mission you'll all be dead.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Damar. Let's not spoil this special moment with predictions of doom. Even you have to appreciate the audacity of Captain Sisko's plan.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Personally, I think we'd be better off launching an orbital assault on Gowron's Command Center. A full spread of photon torpedoes would take care of him, the Klingon High Command and everyone else within a few hundred kilometers.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: You should ask Dukat for some shore leave. I think you've been in space too long.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Why? Because I'm willing to spill a little Klingon blood to get the job done?
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Shelling Ty'Gokor won't get the job done. You'd be lucky to launch one torpedo before they shot you down. And even a dozen wouldn't penetrate the shielding around the command center.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Thank you for the input, Mister Damar, but we'll stick to our original plan. Are you making any progress on our Klingon identity files?
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Don't worry, Captain, by the time we get to Ty'Gokor, we'll have something suitably impressive to plant in their central computer system.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Our names must be added to the list of candidates for the Order of the Bat'leth.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: The Order of the Bat'leth? Don't you think you might be overdoing it?
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: They'll be inducting new members in a few days. And Chancellor Gowron will be presiding over the ceremony.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: That should make for an interesting evening.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: I certainly hope so. I assume you know the way to Ty'Gokor? DEEP SPACE NINE: "Apocalypse... " - REV. 07/19/96 - ACT TWO 21.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Oh, I think I can get us there.
scene: 30   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Here are the results of the crew physicals.
Anything interesting?
Lieutenant Vilix'pran is budding again.
You're kidding. How many will this make?
Let's see, he had two from the last litter, and four before that. Could be anywhere from eight to eighteen.
He'll need bigger quarters again.
He said the request will be on your desk in the morning.
Eighteen. I just hope I can survive one.
You're doing great.
I don't feel great.
You're positively glowing.
Really?
I think so. But then, I don't suppose my opinion counts.
It counts. But don't forget, this... ... is still your fault.
My fault?
You performed the transfer from Keiko to me.
After you volunteered.
After you put the idea in my head.
After you flew the runabout into the asteroid field.
After you insisted we check on those anomalous bio-scans.
That was Keiko.
That's right. It was. But I'd rather blame you.
Whatever makes you happy. I never argue with my patients... or my commanding officer.
You think they'll make it?
They'll make it. (trying to lighten things up) The question is, will you be able to give them their old faces back?
Let's start with you.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: I'm waiting.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: I don't understand. What exactly...
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: I am not interested in excuses. Are you a Klingon warrior or an Alverian dung beetle?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Don't look away from me. I called you a dung beetle.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: I heard you.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: And what is your response?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: You should have your eyes checked.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: This is not going to work. It is not enough to look like a Klingon, one must act like one. Perhaps it would be better if I went by my...
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Are you questioning the validity of my plan?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Very convincing, Captain. But was it your intention to challenge me to a battle to the death?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Not at all.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Then next time do not strike me with the back of your hand. Use your fist.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: This is more complicated than I thought.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: You should think twice before insulting a Klingon like that.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: What did I do?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Look at you. You stand so far away from me. You speak so quietly. Are you afraid of me... or disgusted by my presence?
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Klingon warriors speak to each other proudly. They don't whisper. or keep their distance.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Sorry! I'll do better next time.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Keep practicing.
scene: 33   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BACK ROOM

quote: Constable...
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: Captain, I have no business being on this mission. I'm not a very convincing Klingon.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: Then you'd better work on becoming one. Because like it or not, you are on this mission.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: I'd hate to be the reason it fails.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: Let me worry about that. Odo, I know this has been a difficult time for you. That you never would've chosen to become a Solid. But what's done is done. Brooding isn't going to change anything. And shirking your responsibilities isn't going to make you feel better about yourself.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: No, I don't suppose it will.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: Then I suggest you get back in there and do your job.
scene: 33A  INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - ANOTHER ROOM

quote: What's going on, Dukat?
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: We're being hailed by another bird of prey.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: What are you doing about it?
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: We're hailing them back. I wouldn't worry. This happens all the time.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Sir, they're requesting visual contact.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: By all means.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: It's a shame you can't see the holo-image I'm projecting over the comm system. I make quite an imposing Klingon.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Sir, the holofilter's not working.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: What do you mean it's not working?
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Let me take a look at it.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: They're repeating the request.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: The optronic relays are fused.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Maybe we should have Worf speak to them.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: I might be able to convince them that...
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: I have a better idea.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: You should've let me speak to them.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: was that really necessary?
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: It was either that or trust in Mister Worf's ability to lie. Frankly I have more faith in my weapons. Get us out of here. I want to put as much distance as possible between us and the wreckage.
scene: 34   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE (OPTICAL)

quote: I hope I can remember how to set this thing up.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: If that is a joke, I'm not amused.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: It's not easy to be funny wearing these teeth.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Well, captain, I've enjoyed your company as always. But it appears it's time we said good-bye. I don't envy your assignment.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: orbiting this place for the next day or so won't be the safest job in the galaxy either.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Which is why we'll be leaving as soon as you beam down.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Leaving? For how long?
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: I really don't see any pressing need to come back.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: That wasn't what we agreed to.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: I realize that. But how long do you think we can stay here undetected without the holofilter? Besides, if you succeed the war will be over and you won't need us. And if you fail...
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Did you add our "names" to the Commendation List?
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: I haven't survived this long by being sloppy. And now Jodmos Son of Kobor... your medal awaits you.
scene: 41   INT. DUKAT'S BIRD OF PREY - BRIDGE

quote: Cho'Ghos!
Are you all right?
I'm fine. But I wish they'd stop ringing that bell.
(with a sense of history) The Hall of Warriors.
You can smell the blood of history in these stones. Come, we must celebrate.
Now what?
Now... we celebrate.
... I was the first to board their starship. With one blow from my Bat'leth, I beheaded their helmsman. A Tellarite. The pig didn't even have time to raise his weapon.
Then I turned my attention to the Captain. A Benzenite named Laporin.
He put up a valiant struggle. But in the end, I ripped the breathing tubes from his head and...
Brag all you want, but don't get between me and the bloodwine.
You knew Captain Laporin.
We went to the Academy together.
How long until Gowron gets here?

Many hours. I suspect he will not appear until tomorrow morning at the earliest. This is an endurance test as much as a party. It's part of the initiation rite for the Order of the Bat'leth. The idea is to eat, drink, stay awake all night and still be clear-eyed when Gowron arrives for the ceremony.
So when do we set up the emitters?
Not until morning. I want to minimize the chance of anyone spotting them once they're in place.
In that case, we might as well drink up. Pity it doesn't have any bubbles.
I think I'm actually starting to like bloodwine.
It's really not too bad... except for the taste.
Just be thankful that the anti- intoxicant we took is still working... or we'd all be so drunk we couldn't walk.
Not bad.
Captain of the Academy wrestling team...
... Twenty-two years ago.
Martok. Glory to you. Success! Long live the Empire. Victory is ours. Hail Martok.
Sir.
I see him.
Martok the Victor. Martok the Conqueror. May your Bat'leth run red. Success.
What if he recognizes us?
Then we've come a long way for nothing.
Q'apla!
Martok, Q'apla!
Q'apla.
If Martok is here, Gowron won't be far behind.
Let's get it done.
Hold on there.
Don't I know you?
I... I would be honored to think so.
I know we have met.
I am Pahash of the House of Konjah.
Your name is not familiar to me. But there is something about you...
Perhaps we met on the battlefield. My regiment fought at Mempa.
Mempa. Many noble deeds were done on that dark day.
And yours have become legend.
Yes, Mempa. That must be it.
After the ceremony would you honor me with a drink?
We will salute the fallen.
It is a very familiar face.
Where's Gowron?
What is this?
Get away from me or you won't live to see Gowron.
I'll take that.
This looks like some sort of weapon.
Kodrak! My brother.
You found it.
Found what?
It's a tinghamut.
A what?
A Vulcan toy. For children.
The spoils of war. From the raid on Archanis.
If you want one, you'll have to find your own.
Here. Give it to your son.
I'll make sure he gets it.
Hail Gowron! Long live the Empire! Gowron! Victory! etc.
Long live Gowron! Long live the Empire!
Klingon Warriors, I salute you. At least, those of you still on your feet.
This is a great day for the Empire, a day when we honor you who have brought us glory, who's deeds of valor will live on in song and story.
Here in this hallowed hall, under the watchful gaze of our greatest heroes, you will receive the highest honor that can be bestowed upon a Klingon. The Order of the Bat'leth.
Come forward, H'Ta son of Kahmar.
Glory to you and your house.
Come forward, T'vis, son of Barot.
This is my place. Step down.
Find another.
Glory to you and your house.
That won't be necessary.
Come forward, Huss, daughter of Altrom.
Glory to you and your house.
Come forward, Jodmos, son of Kobor.
Glory to you and your house.
Captain Benjamin Sisko. I knew I recognized that face. Seal the room.
It seems we have some uninvited guests.
Captain, you don't know how much I've looked forward to killing you in battle. And now your foolishness has cheated me of that pleasure.
Sorry to disappoint you.
Leave us.
You heard me.
Don't you understand? You've thrown your lives away for nothing.
Or did you really think you could fool us into believing that Chancellor Gowron was a Dominion spy?
"Gowron" is the one who's fooling you. And as long as you follow him, the Empire will be nothing but a pawn of the Founders.
Where is your proof?
You want proof? Take our polaron emitters and use them on Gowron.
Gowron had your equipment destroyed.
Of course he did. He had to make sure he couldn't be tested.
Your mission was a failure, Captain. And for that, you deserve to die.
Would you be happier if we'd succeeded?
I'm a loyal officer of the Empire.
You think we're right, don't you? You believe Gowron's a changeling, too.
That would be treason.
Since when is it treasonous to act in the best interests of the Empire?
How long have you suspected?

I have known Gowron a long time. And it is no secret that we have not always agreed on the way he runs the Empire. He is a politician... too eager to compromise... To talk. Last year, he stopped the attack on Deep Space Nine instead of going to war with the Federation.
But then... he changed. Suddenly he was the one calling for war.
I'd think that would've made you happy.

At first, it did. But after the war began, he started ignoring the counsel of his generals, throwing aside all wisdom in his pursuit of victory. Our losses continue to mount, and still he listens to no one.
No one but the Founders.
There's only one certain way to expose Gowron for what he really is. To prove beyond a shadow of a doubt that he is a changeling. Gowron must die.
Once he's dead, he will revert to his natural form and eliminate all doubt.
You could challenge him to honorable combat.
There will be no honorable combat, no formal challenges. I will release you, help you reach the Hall of Warriors, and then you will kill him.
The prisoners will come with me for further interrogation.
You heard me. Let them out.
General, I have strict orders from Gowron himself. The prisoners are not to leave this cell.
I see. Well, we wouldn't want to disobey the Chancellor.
Follow me.
For the Empire.
Let's go.
Not you. There's no telling where your loyalties lie.
What? Another toast?
(lifting his glass to one of the statues) Then let us salute Rurik the Damned, conqueror of the Zora Fel, liberator of Vrax...
What is this?
It is your death.
No.
Lower your weapons. If this traitor wants a fight, I will give him one.
You want to kill me, Worf. You're welcome to try.
What are they doing? Why doesn't Sisko just shoot him?
I have a better question. Why isn't Gowron letting his bodyguards kill Worf?

I'll tell you why. Klingon honor. A concept you should be very familiar with. My people, on the other hand, don't care about honor. How did you put it? "There will be no honorable combat, no formal challenges." Hardly the words of a Klingon.
Tell me, "General," did Gowron destroy the polaron emitters... or did you?
Worf, stop!
Gowron's not the changeling. It's Martok.
Well, it looks like we found our changeling after all.
So the Founders misled Odo into thinking I was a spy, hoping that you'd eliminate me and pave the way for that... thing imitating Martok to take over the Empire.
That way, the war between the Federation and the Klingons would continue until both sides were destroyed.
Leaving the Alpha Quadrant wide open for a Dominion invasion.
That seems to have been their plan.
And we played right into it.
But they sorely underestimated Odo here.
Thank you.
If we really want to strike a blow against the Founders, we have to find a way to end this war.
That may not be possible.
Why not? You told us that the Martok changeling was the one who pushed for the attack on the Federation.

True. But if your Klingon blood wasn't so thin you'd know that once battle has begun, there can be no turning back. You want the war to end, then the Federation must allow us to annex Archanis and the other worlds we've seized.
I wouldn't count on it. But if the fighting stops and negotiations begin...
Ah, yes. Talk.
That's right. Talk. The last thing the Dominion wants.
I will call a meeting of the High Council. Advise a temporary cease fire.
And where Gowron leads, the Council will follow.
Perhaps. I'll see to it that you're safely delivered back to that space station of yours. SISKO I'd appreciate that.
I'd appreciate that.
You have done a great service to the Empire. For that, I thank you.
As for you... you should've killed me when you had the chance. I promise you won't get another.
Now that's better, isn't it?
I don't know. I could do without ridges... but I kind of miss the fangs.
That leaves you, Odo.
It's about time. I, for one, won't miss the fangs at all.
You know, Constable, I could give you any face you want. Bajoran. Human. Trill.
My old face will do nicely, thank you.
You heard the man.
Whatever you say.
If I had known what I was walking into, I never would've gone.
It was your idea to attend the conference in the first place, Garak.
I thought the Bajorans would be grateful to hear someone provide them with an opposing philosophical view.
"Opposing view?" Garak, you were trying to defend the military occupation of their world. How grateful did you think they would be?
My understanding was that this conference was supposed to be an examination of the occupation from a dispassionate historical perspective.
But instead, everyone went out of their way to dismiss virtually everything I had to say.
I thought the Bajorans bent over backwards to be polite to you, Garak.
Giving me a name tag that said, "Elim Garak -- Former Cardassian Oppressor" was hardly polite.
What did you want it to say? "Former Spy?"

What I would've liked was less posturing and more debate. It's clear to me now that the Bajorans aren't really interested in discovering historical truth so much as they are in promoting the myths and legends of the "glorious Resistance."
Odo wasn't a member of the Resistance and he attracted a fair amount of attention.
Yes, it seems you have quite a fan club on Bajor. I half expected you to be signing autographs at the end.
Don't let him get to you, Odo. You should be proud of what you did during the Occupation.
I have nothing to be proud of. I tried to... bring order to a chaotic situation, that's all.
Give yourself some credit, Constable. Keeping order in the middle of the Occupation would be a tough job for anyone. But you not only did it -- you did it by earning the trust of both sides.
What was it the Moderator said? "You may have worked for the Cardassians, but your only master was Justice."
And a legend is born.
I may be ill.
Sir -- Captain Sisko's runabout is approaching the station.
Very well. Clear them for docking on Landing Pad One.
Aye, sir.
Commander, something's wrong. They're not responding, and sensors show unusual EM signatures along their hull.
The runabout's on auto-pilot...
Lifesigns?
Four... very weak.
Disengage the auto-pilot and bring the ship to within transporter range.
Check the aft compartment.
He's alive... but there's an excess of neural energy in his cerebral cortex...
What does that mean?
I'm not sure...
Can you revive them?
I'm not sure of that, either...
Show some dignity.
Look at you -- no wonder the Cardassians think we're animals. Get up! Get up!
Who... who are you?
If you're going to spend the night taking chemicals, stay off the Promenade. We don't need another cleansing today.
It can't be...
What happened... ?
Not here.
I couldn't agree more.
There's a high level of neural activity... which suggests their conscious minds are active... but there's no response to any external stimuli.
What's the word on the runabout?
We've found preliminary indications that the ship encountered a class two plasma storm which irradiated the vessel.
Computer, are current neural readings for subjects Sisko, Odo, Dax and Garak consistent with the effects of encountering a class two plasma storm?
There are no recorded causal relationships between plasma storms and specified neural readings.
None? Computer, how many medical records are there on space plasma phenomena?
Five thousand, twenty-one.
So we're dealing with a fairly common phenomenon, having an uncommon effect on our people.
The runabout is still being analyzed. They may have more information soon.
Good. In the meantime... I have some reading to do.
This is Terok Nor... D.S. Nine during the occupation.
Time travel?
It's more than that. Our clothes have changed.
Could we be in a holosuite?
Computer, end program.
Let's assume that's a no for the moment.
Benjamin... we're not attracting any attention.
And we should be.
Humans, Trills and changelings didn't just stroll through Terok Nor unnoticed.
I should be getting some attention too... we're in the Bajoran sector... Cardassians weren't exactly welcome here.
Out of my way.
A Bajoran would never touch a Cardassian during the Occupation. At least, not publicly.
I don't think they see you as a Cardassian. And I'm beginning to think they don't see any of us as who we really are.
The clothes we're wearing are Bajoran... and they're treating us like Bajorans...
Maybe they see us as Bajorans. Any theories, old man?
Some kind of... cross-dimensional transfer? Our conscious minds might've been moved through time and space into the bodies of four Bajorans on Terok Nor.
But then why do we still see each other as we really are instead of as Bajorans?
I just ran out of speculation.
The last thing I remember was... sitting in the runabout...
There was a plasma anomaly on the sensors... and then I heard this sound...
No, not a sound -- more like a strong vibration...
I remember. Odo?
I don't recall.
Then I suggest we go directly to the authorities and explain our situation.
Garak...

I have knowledge of certain... security codes that should be sufficient to prove that I am in fact a Cardassian even if their eyes say otherwise. I can always say that I'm an undercover operative posing as a Bajoran and --

Captain, the authorities on Terok Nor will not be looking for reasons to help us. They'll be looking for a reason to interrogate us, and believe me, you do not want to be interrogated by the Cardassians.
I tend to agree with the constable. If they should discover that we're actually from the future --
Dukat's on the second level.
Let's move on.
Odo.
Who was that?
I... don't know.
You should. He was your predecessor.
My predecessor... ? Oh. Yes. The man talking to Dukat. His name is Thrax. He was in charge of security on the Promenade before me.
Then that means we've gone back at least nine years.
You. Come with us.
What's she done?
Nothing. Yet. Come on.
Perhaps there's been some misunderstanding. If I may be so bold -- you may find something which will bring you infinitely more profit than the arrest of a Bajoran woman.
Latinum?
Two strips.
Where is it?
Our friend is still in custody.
I'll be all right.
Tempting offer. Maybe next time. This one's been selected.
Doctor Bashir!
There.
Garak's septial capillaries burst at this point. And the pattern of his delta waves shows unusual activity at the same moment.
The bleeding might be the result of some kind of psychosomatic response.
You mean he... thought that he was injured?
Under certain conditions, people have been known to alter their blood pressure, lower their body temperature, even manifest tumors as a result of psychological stimuli.
Could these... stimuli cause more serious injuries?
I don't think he could spontaneously break a bone, but he could certainly stop his heart or burst a key blood vessel in his brain.
But what is causing all this?
At the risk of repeating myself... I just don't know.
He said she was "selected." What the hell does that mean?
A random interrogation, forced labor relocation -- it could be anything.
Before we can help Commander Dax, we need to find out who we are in this... reality.
If we could get to a computer terminal, we could ask for a simple ID scan.
Computer access was extremely limited on Terok Nor.
What about a Cardassian comp-link?
I took the liberty of borrowing this from the gentlemen who thought my nose needed adjustment.
I see I'll have to add the word pickpocket to your resume.
It's just a hobby.
Interesting that a simple tailor just happens to have a high-level security code.
Isn't it? If my nose didn't hurt so much, I'd entertain you with a fascinating story of how I came to possess it.
Well Captain, it seems you're actually a Bajoran electronics engineer...
... you're thirty-eight years old... you have no criminal record... your family resides in Rakantha province...
... and your name is Ishan Chaye.
Oh, lucky me. I'm an artist.
I'm fifty-five... been arrested three times for disturbing the peace -- I must be incorrigible -- I also come from Rakantha...
... and my name is Jillur Gueta.
And the Constable?
Let's see... Ah. His profession is --
